HOME WOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 19, 1935.

4

Loyola Quint Jay Walks
Beats Hopkins Aftermath
In Extra Period Of A Game
By KEN ZIERLER

Greyhounds Score 5 Points
In Extra Period When
Count Is Knotted By Jays

Lead Alternates
Siverd's Tally Evens Score
At End Of Regular Cantos;
Frosh Take Preliminary
In keeping with all expectations,
the Hopkins-Loyola basketball game,
held at the Hopkins gymnasium last
Saturday, proved to be another spectacular, breath-taking encounter. The
regular game ended in a tie, 22-all.
In the extra period the Jesuits drew
away from the frantic Jays and won,
27 to 24.
Both teams were apparently tense
and excited as the fray opened. Close
defense systems made shooting opportunities few and far between. For
the greater part of the period the
Jays and Jesuits alternately held onepoint leads. Then the Evergreen stalwarts began to locate the rim from
long range and were six points ahead
at half-time. Throughout this period Harry Woodrow performed brilliantly for the Darleymen.
Jays Rally
As the second canto opened, the
Loyola team added to its lead. Victory seemed certain for the Jesuits.
The Jays, with their backs to the
wall, staged an infuriated comeback.
Siegel tallied first and in rapid succession Chancellor accounted for two
more baskets. Two long hawkers by
Captain Siverd knotted the count as
the final gun sounded.
Amid the sustained uproar of the
fans, it was decided to play a fiveminute extra period. Too anxious to
score, the Jays were erratic in their
shooting. The Greyhounds, however,
settled down immediately. Taneyhill
pushed a rebound into the basket to
place Loyola ahead. Soon after Colvin converted a foul. Wayson's basket clinched the game for the Jesuits.
Siegel made the only Hopkins tally
in this period.
In a preliminary encounter, the Jay
freshmen defeated the Loyola yearlings, 20 to 11. Kempton, Tragis, and
Rosenthal were outstanding for the
frosh.

When Cliff Siverd said to Referee
Jack Enright, "How about giving us
a break?" Loyola was awarded a
technical foul which it converted into
a point.. Were it not for that, Hopkins might have won, 22-21, in the
regular playing time. The quality of
the officiating still does not excuse
the childish attitude of the stands.
Opposition players, who have nothing
to do with the way the referee sees
the play, should be given a fair
chance to sink their foul shots.
Harry Woodrow looked like allstate material for fifteen minutes in
the first half. Carl Rasin, injured in
practice, was obviously not himself.
Cliff Siverd gave further demonstration that there is no one in the league
who can anticipate and Intercept
passes better than he. Herbie Siegel
holds the record for spills. Opie Chancellor holds the record for fouls. He
must think there is a referees' conspiracy against him.
To cap it all, Loyola, leading the
league, isn't as good a five as Mt. St.
Mary's.

Fencers Foil
St. John's
Led by Herman, Bike and Sherman
the University fencing team easily
defeated the St. John's swordsmen by
a score of 15 matches to 2.
In the foil matches, which were
held first, the Jay duelists lost only
one match out of nine. Herman taking three matches, Sherman three,
and Reed two. The Johnnies fared
better in the epee matches only losing
by a score of 3 to 1.
In the sabre matches the Hopkins
fencers won all four of the matches.

The Blue tankmen scored their first
victory of the season at the expense
of the George Washington Itatators,
36 to 32, in the Shoreham Hotel Pool.
Not until the last event, the 400yard relay, in which Jones, Noonan,
Scherr and L. Adler secured victory,
was the meet decided.
Johnny MacGill set up a new Hopkins record for the 150-yard backstroke, negotiating the distance in 1
minute 55 1-5 seconds, one and fifth
seconds better than the old record.
Lou Adler was a double winner in
the 50-yard free style and in the 100yard free' style. In the latter event
he was followed by Don Noonan.
Danny Weiner trailed MacGill in the
150-yard backstroke. Other Hopkins
point garnerers were Scheer, Koenig,
McConnell, J. Adler and Hazlett.

All-Star Class Fives
To Face Each Other
In Series In March
Varsity Courtmen Eligible To
Play On Frosh, Soph, Junior, Or Senior Quints
In March, four all-star basketball
teams, each representing a class, will
meet in a series to decide the championship of the college. Members of
the varsity quintet will be eligible to
play on the stellar fives of their respective years.
Prior to this, the winner of the
non-fraternity league will be matched
against the champion of the fraternity league. The non-fraternity team
will be selected from the winner of a
series of games between the freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior
class champs.
So far, only in the junior class
league is the winner determined. In a
thrilling play-off on Thursday afternoon, the Junior Gas-Engineers defeated the Electrical Engineers by a
score of 12 to 11. The soph champ
will be crowned this afternoon when
the Sophomore Gasmen, winners of
Division I, will meet the Sophomore
Mechanics, winners of Division II.
On Wednesday, Castelle's Musicians
will meet the New Jersey All-Stars
for the freshman title. The senior
winner will be decided on Thursday
when the Senior Businessmen play
the Senior Chemists, both winners of
their respective divisions.
Each member of the inter-class
championship team will be awarded a
medal.

.and tobacco has been like gold ever since!
The tobacco raised in Virginia and exchanged
for goods helped the struggling colonists to get a
foothold when they came to America.
Later on, it was tobacco that helped to clothe
and feed Washington's brave army at Valley
Forge.
Today it is tobacco that helps—more than any
other commodity raised in this country—to pay
the expense of running our Government.
In the fiscal year 1933-34 the Federal
Government collected $425,000,000 from
the tax on tobacco. Most, of this came
from cigarettes — six cents tax on 'every
package of twenty.
Yes, the cigarette helps a lot—and it certainly
gives men and women a lot of pleasure.

Chesterfields. For one thing, Chesterfields
are milder. For another thing, they taste
better. They Satisfy.

HOME WOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 19, 1935.

4

Loyola Quint Jay Walks
Beats Hopkins Aftermath
In Extra Period Of A Game
By KEN ZIERLER

Greyhounds Score 5 Points
In Extra Period When
Count Is Knotted By Jays

Lead Alternates
Siverd's Tally Evens Score
At End Of Regular Cantos;
Frosh Take Preliminary
In keeping with all expectations,
the Hopkins-Loyola basketball game,
held at the Hopkins gymnasium last
Saturday, proved to be another spectacular, breath-taking encounter. The
regular game ended in a tie, 22-all.
In the extra period the Jesuits drew
away from the frantic Jays and won,
27 to 24.
Both teams were apparently tense
and excited as the fray opened. Close
defense systems made shooting opportunities few and far between. For
the greater part of the period the
Jays and Jesuits alternately held onepoint leads. Then the Evergreen stalwarts began to locate the rim from
long range and were six points ahead
at half-time. Throughout this period Harry Woodrow performed brilliantly for the Darleymen.
Jays Rally
As the second canto opened, the
Loyola team added to its lead. Victory seemed certain for the Jesuits.
The Jays, with their backs to the
wall, staged an infuriated comeback.
Siegel tallied first and in rapid succession Chancellor accounted for two
more baskets. Two long hawkers by
Captain Siverd knotted the count as
the final gun sounded.
Amid the sustained uproar of the
fans, it was decided to play a fiveminute extra period. Too anxious to
score, the Jays were erratic in their
shooting. The Greyhounds, however,
settled down immediately. Taneyhill
pushed a rebound into the basket to
place Loyola ahead. Soon after Colvin converted a foul. Wayson's basket clinched the game for the Jesuits.
Siegel made the only Hopkins tally
in this period.
In a preliminary encounter, the Jay
freshmen defeated the Loyola yearlings, 20 to 11. Kempton, Tragis, and
Rosenthal were outstanding for the
frosh.

When Cliff Siverd said to Referee
Jack Enright, "How about giving us
a break?" Loyola was awarded a
technical foul which it converted into
a point.. Were it not for that, Hopkins might have won, 22-21, in the
regular playing time. The quality of
the officiating still does not excuse
the childish attitude of the stands.
Opposition players, who have nothing
to do with the way the referee sees
the play, should be given a fair
chance to sink their foul shots.
Harry Woodrow looked like allstate material for fifteen minutes in
the first half. Carl Rasin, injured in
practice, was obviously not himself.
Cliff Siverd gave further demonstration that there is no one in the league
who can anticipate and Intercept
passes better than he. Herbie Siegel
holds the record for spills. Opie Chancellor holds the record for fouls. He
must think there is a referees' conspiracy against him.
To cap it all, Loyola, leading the
league, isn't as good a five as Mt. St.
Mary's.

Fencers Foil
St. John's
Led by Herman, Bike and Sherman
the University fencing team easily
defeated the St. John's swordsmen by
a score of 15 matches to 2.
In the foil matches, which were
held first, the Jay duelists lost only
one match out of nine. Herman taking three matches, Sherman three,
and Reed two. The Johnnies fared
better in the epee matches only losing
by a score of 3 to 1.
In the sabre matches the Hopkins
fencers won all four of the matches.

Chessmen Checkmate
City College

City College chessmen the freshmen
chess team won their first victory of
the current season Wednesday afternoon in Levering Hall by a score of 3
matches to 2.

victory of the season at the expense
of the George Washington Itatators,

was the meet decided.
Johnny MacGill set up a new Hopkins record for the 150-yard backstroke, negotiating the distance in 1
minute 55 1-5 seconds, one and fifth
seconds better than the old record.
Lou Adler was a double winner in
the 50-yard free style and in the 100yard free' style. In the latter event
he was followed by Don Noonan.
Danny Weiner trailed MacGill in the
150-yard backstroke. Other Hopkins
point garnerers were Scheer, Koenig,
McConnell, J. Adler and Hazlett.

All-Star Class Fives
To Face Each Other
In Series In March
Varsity Courtmen Eligible To
Play On Frosh, Soph, Junior, Or Senior Quints
In March, four all-star basketball
teams, each representing a class, will
meet in a series to decide the championship of the college. Members of
the varsity quintet will be eligible to
play on the stellar fives of their respective years.
Prior to this, the winner of the
non-fraternity league will be matched
against the champion of the fraternity league. The non-fraternity team
will be selected from the winner of a
series of games between the freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior
class champs.
So far, only in the junior class
league is the winner determined. In a
thrilling play-off on Thursday afternoon, the Junior Gas-Engineers defeated the Electrical Engineers by a
score of 12 to 11. The soph champ
will be crowned this afternoon when
the Sophomore Gasmen, winners of
Division I, will meet the Sophomore
Mechanics, winners of Division II.
On Wednesday, Castelle's Musicians
will meet the New Jersey All-Stars
for the freshman title. The senior
winner will be decided on Thursday
when the Senior Businessmen play
the Senior Chemists, both winners of
their respective divisions.
Each member of the inter-class
championship team will be awarded a
medal.

.and tobacco has been like gold ever since!
The tobacco raised in Virginia and exchanged
for goods helped the struggling colonists to get a
foothold when they came to America.
Later on, it was tobacco that helped to clothe
and feed Washington's brave army at Valley
Forge.
Today it is tobacco that helps—more than any
other commodity raised in this country—to pay
the expense of running our Government.
In the fiscal year 1933-34 the Federal
Government collected $425,000,000 from
the tax on tobacco. Most, of this came
from cigarettes — six cents tax on 'every
package of twenty.
Yes, the cigarette helps a lot—and it certainly
gives men and women a lot of pleasure.
